title: Understanding Ovarian Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value:
Ovarian cancer is a cancer that begins in the ovaries — the two small organs responsible for producing eggs and hormones such as oestrogen and progesterone.

It is often called a **"silent" cancer** because early symptoms can be vague and easily mistaken for digestive or menstrual issues.

**Early detection greatly improves outcomes.**

content.description: Epithelial ovarian cancer accounts for 90% of all ovarian cancer cases.

content.value: Ovarian cancer can develop in different types of cells inside the ovary. Understanding where it starts helps doctors diagnose the type and plan the most effective treatment.

items.title: Epithelial Ovarian Cancer
items.description: The most common type — around 90% of all ovarian cancers. It begins in the cells covering the surface of the ovary or fallopian tubes.

items.title: Germ Cell Tumours
items.description: Start in the cells that produce eggs. These are less common and tend to affect younger women.

items.title: Stromal Tumours
items.description: Begin in the hormone-producing cells of the ovary. They are rare and often detected earlier because they can cause hormone-related symptoms.

content.title: Did You Know?
content.description: Some ovarian cancers begin in the fallopian tubes and spread to the ovary — but they are still grouped as ovarian cancer.

content.value: Not everyone with risk factors will develop ovarian cancer, but they increase likelihood.

steps: Age (Especially After 50) — Most ovarian cancers occur after menopause.
Family History of Ovarian, Breast, or Colorectal Cancer — Close relatives with these cancers increase your genetic risk.
Inherited Mutations (BRCA1, BRCA2, Lynch Syndrome) — These mutations significantly increase ovarian cancer risk.
Endometriosis — Long-term endometriosis is linked to certain ovarian cancer types.
Never Having Been Pregnant — Women who have never carried a pregnancy have a slightly higher risk.
Long-Term Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) — Extended use of estrogen-only HRT may increase risk.
Obesity — Higher body fat can influence hormone levels that affect risk.

content.title: Good to Know
content.description: Having one or more risk factors does not mean you will get ovarian cancer — but understanding them helps with early detection and prevention.

content.value: Ovarian cancer can cause a variety of symptoms. Some of the most common include:

items.text: Loss of appetite or feeling full after eating small amounts
Frequent or urgent need to urinate

content.title: Important
content.description: If you experience these symptoms, it's important to see your GP for further tests.

content.value: Several tests and scans can help identify ovarian cancer, including:

content.title: Diagnostic Process
content.description: Your doctor will use a combination of tests to confirm diagnosis and determine staging

items.title: CT scan
items.description: Produces detailed images of the ovaries and shows abnormalities

items.title: X-ray
items.description: Checks if cancer has spread to other areas of the body

items.title: Biopsy
items.description: Tissue or cells are examined for cancer

items.title: Laparoscopy
items.description: A small camera is inserted into the abdomen to directly examine the ovaries

content.title: Note
content.description: If ovarian cancer is suspected, these tests also help determine how far the cancer has spread.

content.value: Treatment depends on the type of ovarian cancer, your overall health, and fertility considerations.

content.title: Treatment Goal
content.description: The main goal is to remove the cancer whenever possible

items.title: Surgery + Chemotherapy
items.content: Often used together as first-line treatment. Surgery removes visible cancer while chemotherapy targets remaining cancer cells.

items.title: Targeted Therapies
items.content: PARP inhibitors, Angiogenesis inhibitors, and MEK inhibitors target specific pathways in cancer cells.

items.title: Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy
items.content: Delivering chemotherapy directly into the abdominal cavity for more targeted treatment.

items.title: Radiation Therapy
items.content: Especially effective for isolated recurrences in the pelvic area.

items.title: Clinical Trials
items.content: Access to new and emerging treatments through research programs.

items.title: Complementary Therapies
items.content: Supportive care to improve wellbeing alongside main treatment.

content.value: While there is no screening test for ovarian cancer, several steps can lower risk.

content.title: Why Prevention Matters
content.description: Ovarian cancer often develops silently. While there is no reliable screening test, knowing your risks and making informed choices can significantly reduce the likelihood.

items.text: Genetic testing if you have a strong family history
Using oral contraceptives (long-term use lowers risk)
Being aware of symptoms and seeking prompt evaluation

content.value: The most important points to remember about ovarian cancer.
**Persistent bloating, pelvic pain, or feeling full quickly should not be ignored.**
